subject: statistics
title: Type I and Type II Errors
contentHtml:
In statistical hypothesis testing, we often encounter two types of errors: Type I and Type II.

A Type I error occurs when we reject a true null hypothesis, while a Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis. Understanding these errors is crucial for making informed decisions in various fields, including machine learning and artificial intelligence.

formula.latex: \(\alpha = P(Type I error) + P(Type II error)\)
formula.name: Significance Level

intuition: Think of Type I errors as false positives (rejecting a true null hypothesis) and Type II errors as false negatives (failing to reject a false null hypothesis). A good test should strike a balance between these two types.
realWorldApplications: In ML, understanding type I and type II errors helps in selecting the right evaluation metrics for model performance.
commonMistakes: Failing to consider both Type I and Type II errors when designing a hypothesis test

subject: statistics
statementHtml: Consider a statistical test with significance level α = 0.05. What is the probability of making a Type I error?
hints: Think about the definition of a Type I error.
Recall that α represents the maximum acceptable probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis.
Use the formula for the probability of a Type I error.
solutionHtml:
To find the probability of making a Type I error, we need to recall the definition:

\(\mathbf{P(Type\ I\ Error) = P(Reject\ H_0 | H_0\ true)}.\)

Since α represents the maximum acceptable probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis, we can set up an inequality:

\(\mathbf{P(Type\ I\ Error) ≤ α}.\)

Solving for P(Type I Error), we get:

\(\mathbf{P(Type\ I\ Error) = α}.\)

This means that the probability of making a Type I error is equal to the significance level.
